drug_class: Tetracycline antibiotic; Bacteriostatic antimicrobial agent with broad-spectrum activity against gram-positive, gram-negative, atypical bacteria, and certain parasites
mechanism_of_action: Doxycycline reversibly binds to the 30S ribosomal subunit of susceptible bacteria, specifically blocking the binding of aminoacyl-tRNA to the acceptor (A) site on the mRNA-ribosome complex. This prevents the addition of amino acids to the growing peptide chain, thereby inhibiting bacterial protein synthesis. Additionally, doxycycline may alter cytoplasmic membrane permeability and has anti-inflammatory properties through inhibition of matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs), phospholipase A2, and reduction of pro-inflammatory cytokines including IL-1β and TNF-α. At subantimicrobial doses, it demonstrates anti-collagenase activity.

pharmacokinetics.absorption: Oral bioavailability: 90-100% (nearly complete absorption). Peak plasma concentrations (Cmax) achieved in 1.5-4 hours after oral administration. Food and dairy products have minimal effect on absorption compared to other tetracyclines, though high-fat meals may slightly delay absorption. Absorption occurs primarily in the stomach and upper small intestine.
pharmacokinetics.metabolism: Minimal hepatic metabolism. Does not undergo significant CYP450-mediated metabolism. Small amounts may be metabolized to inactive metabolites. Unlike other tetracyclines, doxycycline is not significantly affected by hepatic impairment due to minimal hepatic metabolism and alternative elimination pathways.
pharmacokinetics.elimination: Primary routes: Fecal elimination (20-40% as active drug via biliary excretion and direct intestinal secretion) and renal excretion (23-40% as unchanged drug). Enterohepatic recirculation occurs. Renal clearance: 40-50 mL/min. Does not accumulate significantly in renal impairment due to compensatory fecal elimination. Elimination half-life: 15-25 hours (mean 18-22 hours) in adults with normal renal function.
pharmacokinetics.half_life: 15-25 hours (mean 18-22 hours); may be prolonged to 20-30 hours in patients with severe renal impairment, though clinically insignificant

approved_indications: Respiratory tract infections caused by susceptible organisms (Mycoplasma pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, Streptococcus pneumoniae, Klebsiella species)
Urinary tract infections caused by susceptible organisms
Sexually transmitted infections: uncomplicated urethral, endocervical, or rectal infections caused by Chlamydia trachomatis; nongonococcal urethritis; lymphogranuloma venereum
Rocky Mountain spotted fever, typhus fever, Q fever, rickettsialpox caused by Rickettsiae
Granuloma inguinale caused by Klebsiella granulomatis
Relapsing fever caused by Borrelia recurrentis
Malaria prophylaxis (Plasmodium falciparum in areas with chloroquine resistance)
Adjunctive therapy in acute intestinal amebiasis and severe acne
off_label_uses: Community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) as part of combination therapy
Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) in combination regimens
Malaria treatment (in combination with quinine or other antimalarials)
Bullous pemphigoid and dermatitis herpetiformis (anti-inflammatory effects)
MRSA skin and soft tissue infections (community-acquired strains)
Sclerotherapy for pleural effusions and malignant ascites
clinical_use.standard_dosing: Adults: Initial loading dose of 200 mg on day 1 (given as 100 mg every 12 hours or 200 mg once daily), followed by maintenance dose of 100 mg once daily or 100 mg every 12 hours for more severe infections. For acute infections: 100 mg every 12 hours. For acne: 50-100 mg once or twice daily. For malaria prophylaxis: 100 mg once daily starting 1-2 days before travel, continuing during travel, and for 4 weeks after leaving endemic area. For anthrax post-exposure: 100 mg twice daily for 60 days. Pediatric (>8 years, weight-based): Day 1: 4.4 mg/kg/day divided every 12 hours (max 200 mg/day); maintenance: 2.2 mg/kg/day once daily or divided every 12 hours (max 100 mg/dose). Take with adequate fluid to reduce esophageal irritation.

dose_adjustments.renal_impairment: No dose adjustment required for any degree of renal impairment including end-stage renal disease (ESRD) or dialysis. Doxycycline is not significantly removed by hemodialysis or peritoneal dialysis. Standard dosing can be used safely in patients with CrCl <10 mL/min.
dose_adjustments.hepatic_impairment: No specific dose adjustment recommended for mild to moderate hepatic impairment due to minimal hepatic metabolism. Use with caution in severe hepatic impairment; monitor for adverse effects. Consider alternative therapy if severe hepatic dysfunction present, though doxycycline is generally safer than other tetracyclines in this population.
dose_adjustments.elderly: No routine dose adjustment required. Use standard adult dosing. Monitor for adverse effects and ensure adequate hydration.
dose_adjustments.pregnancy: Pregnancy Category D. Contraindicated in pregnancy, especially after first trimester, due to risk of permanent tooth discoloration, enamel hypoplasia, and inhibition of bone growth in fetus. Use only if potential benefit justifies potential risk and no alternatives available.
dose_adjustments.pediatric_considerations: Generally avoided in children <8 years due to risk of permanent tooth discoloration and enamel hypoplasia. However, may be used for serious infections (e.g., Rocky Mountain spotted fever, anthrax) when benefits outweigh risks. Short courses (≤21 days) appear to have minimal risk of dental staining.

drug_interactions.mechanism: Additive risk of intracranial hypertension (pseudotumor cerebri)
drug_interactions.clinical_effect: Increased risk of benign intracranial hypertension with papilledema, headache, visual disturbances
drug_interactions.management: Avoid concurrent use. If combination necessary, monitor closely for signs of intracranial hypertension

drug_interactions.mechanism: Tetracyclines may potentiate nephrotoxicity of methoxyflurane
drug_interactions.clinical_effect: Fatal renal toxicity, acute tubular necrosis
drug_interactions.management: Contraindicated. Avoid concurrent use

drug_interactions.mechanism: Doxycycline may enhance anticoagulant effect by reducing vitamin K-producing gut flora and possibly direct anticoagulant effects
drug_interactions.clinical_effect: Increased INR and bleeding risk
drug_interactions.management: Monitor INR closely when starting or stopping doxycycline. Adjust warfarin dose as needed

drug_interactions.mechanism: Polyvalent cations form chelation complexes with doxycycline, reducing absorption
drug_interactions.clinical_effect: Decreased doxycycline bioavailability and therapeutic efficacy
drug_interactions.management: Separate administration by at least 2-3 hours

drug_interactions.mechanism: Ferrous and ferric ions chelate with tetracyclines in GI tract
drug_interactions.clinical_effect: Reduced absorption of both doxycycline and iron, decreased efficacy
drug_interactions.management: Separate administration by at least 2-3 hours

drug_interactions.mechanism: Calcium forms insoluble chelates with doxycycline
drug_interactions.clinical_effect: Decreased doxycycline absorption by up to 50%
drug_interactions.management: Separate administration by at least 2 hours

drug_interactions.mechanism: Chelation with polyvalent cations reduces absorption
drug_interactions.clinical_effect: Decreased doxycycline bioavailability
drug_interactions.management: Separate administration by at least 2 hours

drug_interactions.mechanism: Enzyme induction increases hepatic metabolism of doxycycline
drug_interactions.clinical_effect: Reduced doxycycline half-life and serum concentrations, potential treatment failure
drug_interactions.management: Consider increasing doxycycline dose or using alternative antibiotic

drug_interactions.mechanism: CYP450 enzyme induction increases doxycycline metabolism
drug_interactions.clinical_effect: Decreased doxycycline half-life (from 15-24 hours to 7-12 hours), reduced efficacy
drug_interactions.management: Monitor clinical response. May need to increase doxycycline dose or frequency

drug_interactions.mechanism: Hepatic enzyme induction increases doxycycline clearance
drug_interactions.clinical_effect: Shortened doxycycline half-life, subtherapeutic levels
drug_interactions.management: Monitor clinical response. Consider dose adjustment or alternative therapy

drug_interactions.mechanism: Potent CYP450 induction increases doxycycline metabolism
drug_interactions.clinical_effect: Significantly reduced doxycycline serum concentrations and half-life
drug_interactions.management: Avoid combination if possible. If necessary, consider alternative antibiotic or increased doxycycline dosing

drug_interactions.mechanism: Possible reduction in enterohepatic circulation of estrogens or alteration of gut flora
drug_interactions.clinical_effect: Potential decreased contraceptive efficacy (controversial, rare)
drug_interactions.management: Advise backup contraception during treatment and for 7 days after completion

drug_interactions.mechanism: Bacteriostatic doxycycline may antagonize bactericidal activity of penicillins
drug_interactions.clinical_effect: Reduced efficacy of penicillin in serious infections
drug_interactions.management: Avoid concurrent use in serious infections requiring bactericidal therapy

drug_interactions.mechanism: Tetracyclines may displace methotrexate from protein binding and reduce renal clearance
drug_interactions.clinical_effect: Increased methotrexate toxicity risk
drug_interactions.management: Monitor methotrexate levels and toxicity signs. Consider dose adjustment

drug_interactions.mechanism: Doxycycline may increase digoxin absorption by altering gut flora that metabolize digoxin
drug_interactions.clinical_effect: Increased digoxin levels and potential toxicity (in ~10% of patients)
drug_interactions.management: Monitor digoxin levels when starting or stopping doxycycline

drug_interactions.mechanism: Chelation with zinc reduces absorption
drug_interactions.clinical_effect: Modest decrease in doxycycline absorption
drug_interactions.management: Separate administration by 2 hours if possible

drug_interactions.mechanism: Chelation complex formation in GI tract
drug_interactions.clinical_effect: Reduced doxycycline absorption
drug_interactions.management: Separate doses by 2-3 hours

drug_interactions.mechanism: Calcium in dairy products may chelate with doxycycline (less than other tetracyclines)
drug_interactions.clinical_effect: Minimal effect on absorption with doxycycline compared to other tetracyclines
drug_interactions.management: Generally can be taken with food including dairy, but avoid large amounts of dairy at time of dosing

drug_interactions.mechanism: Chronic alcohol use may induce hepatic enzymes
drug_interactions.clinical_effect: Possible decreased doxycycline levels in chronic alcoholics
drug_interactions.management: Monitor clinical response. Moderate alcohol consumption generally acceptable

drug_interactions.mechanism: Magnesium carbonate in quinapril formulation may chelate doxycycline
drug_interactions.clinical_effect: Reduced doxycycline absorption
drug_interactions.management: Separate administration by 2 hours
